isis.stitle: DT/DTA-466 Diesel Engine Service (1990) - NOZZLES - CLEANING, COMPONENT INSPECTION AND REPAIR - COMPONENT INSPECTION AND REPAIR

step1.para:
Use a magnifying glass (part of SE-2202) to inspect the mating surfaces of the nozzle components, particularly the valve stop spacer, nozzle valve body and valve for nicks, scratches or signs of corrosion. Refer to Figure 12.10
.

note.para: Failure of these surfaces to seal properly will result in leakage to the return or to the outside of the nozzle.

svcsubproc.title: Flat Lapping Procedure
svcsubproc.para: Recondition the mating surfaces by flat lapping or replace the components as required.

note.para: Use lapping block set SE-2250. Obtain directly from Bacharach.

step1.para: Prepare the lapping blocks for use by washing them in fuel oil and using a bristle brush. Dry off with filtered compressed air. DO NOT USE WIPING RAGS.
Mix a small amount of lapping compound (1000 grit) into a thin paste using diesel fuel.

note.para: In some areas, prepared lapping compound can be obtained in small tubes.

step1.para: Apply a very small amount of lapping compound (well spread out) to the lapped side of the blocks. Keep this amount at a minimum to obtain the best results.

note.para: Blocks that are grooved on both sides are generally marked to indicate which side is the lapped surface.

step1.para: The part to be lapped should be placed upon the lapping block and moved about in a figure eight pattern.

To equalize the wear in the lapping block, the series of figure eight strokes should start at one side and progress across the block as shown in Figure 12.11
.

Apply only enough pressure to keep the part flat on the block. After four or five "passes", lift the part off the block and clean the compound off by rubbing the part across a clean sheet of paper placed on a flat surface (avoid excessive lapping). If the surface of the lapped part does not appear uniform in reflected light or if there are any depressions around the sealing surfaces, repeat the lapping procedure above (see Note).

note.para: One exception will be for the valve stop spacer. When the lapping process does not remove depressions around the center valve stem hole, the plate may be turned over in "Reassembly", provided good sealing surfaces are present. Otherwise the plate must be replaced with a new one.

figure.caption: Figure 12.11. Pattern of Strokes Used for Flat Lapping.

step1.para: Perform the last step, DRY LAPPING, which produces a mirror-like finish and provides an excellent sealing surface. Proceed as follows:

step2.para: Clean the block in the same manner as described earlier and dry with filtered compressed air. The block used MUST BE FREE OF ANY LAPPING COMPOUND.

Place the part to be lapped on the block surface and move it about in a figure eight pattern across the whole area of the block ( Figure 12.11
). Make four or five passes, then inspect the finish before repeating (if necessary).
Apply only enough pressure to keep the part flat on the block.

note.para: Do not handle parts on the lapped surfaces as corrosion will appear in the areas touched.

svcsubproc.title: Care And Reconditioning Lapping Blocks

note.para: KEEP THE LAPPING BLOCKS COVERED WHEN NOT BEING USED, TO KEEP DUST OR OTHER FOREIGN MATTER FROM THE SURFACE.

It will be necessary to perform a certain amount of maintenance on the lapping blocks to keep them in top condition. The wear will be gradual but, by continued use, worn or low spots in the block must be removed.

svcsubproc.para: A short time spent each day in hand-lapping the blocks will be an effective way of maintaining the finish necessary for quality lapping.

step1.para: The lapping blocks must be thoroughly cleaned before any reconditioning is started. Use a stiff bristle brush (not a wire brush) and scrub the blocks in a good solvent and blow dry with filtered compressed air.
All lapping blocks in a set are involved in the reconditioning procedure outlined below:

step2.para: Spread a small amount of 1000 grit lapping compound (prepared in a paste) on block number 1, assuming the blocks to be numbered 1, 2 and 3.

Lap number 1 and 2 (face to face) together, using a figure eight pattern ( Figure 12.11
). Then take 1 and 3; and finally 2 and 3.

After working 1 and 3 together, wipe off number 2 on a clean sheet of paper placed on a flat surface. Low spots, if any, will appear as dark spots and high spots as bright spots. Continue the lapping procedure until the overall appearance is a uniform gray surface.
Step 3: After the blocks have been refinished, clean them thoroughly in a good solvent using a bristle brush, then blow dry with filtered compressed air.

step1.para: Visually inspect the valve stop spacer pins for deformity or breakage. Replace as required.
Visually inspect the nozzle cap nut for cracks, damaged threads or damaged copper gasket seating face. Replace as necessary.

Check the stem and the body of the valve. When both parts are wet with fuel oil, no sticking should be evident. Pull the valve out of the body about one-third of its length. When released, the valve should slide freely back to the seat. Foreign matter or scratches on the valve will cause it to stick. Carefully inspect before installing the valve.
OPENING PRESSURE ADJUSTMENT: The nozzle opening pressure is increased or decreased by the selection of the appropriate sized spacer.
